title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: This paper reports on the degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by the endophytic fungus Aspergillus bridgerii. The research was conducted in a controlled microcosm environment, where the fungus was isolated from plant tissues and cultivated on nonwoven fabric samples. The results show that Aspergillus bridgerii is capable of breaking down the fabric, with significant degradation observed after 28 days of incubation. The degradation process was characterized by the breakdown of the fabric's polypropylene and polyethylene fibers.  the potential for microorganisms to interact with and alter industrial materials, exceeding their designed lifespan and functionality.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: While traditionally the health impacts of the biotic and abiotic components of indoor air have been assumed to be independent, recent studies indicate the opposite, highlighting the need for a systematic evaluation of their interactions to provide a holistic assessment of the health impacts of indoor air. In this study, we assessed the toxicological relationship between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and air fresheners, an emerging source of abiotic indoor air pollutants. We evaluated the cytotoxic effects of mold and two air fresheners (Brands A and B) on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. We also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using LC-MS. Our results show that both air fresheners were composed of several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions could influence the toxicological interactions. Overall, our study demonstrates the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The knowledge will also allow air freshener manufacturers to formulate products with minimal health impacts.
summary: This study examines the toxicological interactions between Aspergillus fumigatus, a common indoor mold species, and two commercial air fresheners, Brands A and B. The research reveals that the chemical composition of the air fresheners can inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. The cytotoxic effects of the mold and air fresheners were evaluated on A549 cells, and the results indicate that co-exposure to the two toxicants can have synergistic effects on cellular responses. Analysis of the air freshener solutions using Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS) identified several compounds that could contribute to the observed toxicological interactions. The findings suggest that further research is necessary to understand the complex relationships between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air and to inform the development of safer air freshener products.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: This study investigates the antifungal properties of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO) against Alternaria alternata, a fungus causing postharvest diseases in tomatoes. The researchers developed an optimized extraction method for LEO, achieving a higher yield than conventional methods. LEO was found to exhibit potent antifungal activity against A. alternata, inhibiting lesion expansion and suppressing the accumulation of mycotoxins alternariol and tenuazonic acid in tomato fruit. Microscopic and physiological analyses suggest that LEO disrupts membrane integrity, interferes with energy metabolism, and induces oxidative stress, indicating a multi-target antifungal mechanism. The study concludes that LEO has potential as a natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR

summary: This study's findings are limited due to the lack of available abstract. However, it appears to focus on the development and application of ultraperformance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy (FT-NIR) for the detection and risk assessment of mycotoxins in edible herbs.  The research likely involves the use of these analytical techniques to identify and quantify mycotoxins in herbs, which could have implications for human health and multispecies assemblages. title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: This study examines the interaction between human colon cancer cells and mycotoxins produced by the fungus Alternaria alternata, specifically alternariol and deoxynivalenol. The results indicate that hyperglycemic conditions can modulate the response of colon cancer cells to these mycotoxins. The study was conducted in vitro, suggesting that the multispecies assemblage of human cells and fungal toxins was isolated from the complexities of an in vivo environment. However, the findings are limited to this controlled setting and do not provide insight into how these interactions occur in natural or industrial settings.   The mycotoxins in question, alternariol and deoxynivalenol, are produced by fungi that can contaminate a variety of food and industrial materials, including grains and polypropylene packaging. The study's focus on human cells and fungal toxins highlights the complex relationships between human health, industrial materials, and microbial activity in the Anthropocene.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: This study examines the degradation of mycotoxins using various nanomaterials, including nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts. The research highlights the potential of these nanomaterials to accelerate the breakdown of mycotoxins, which are toxic compounds produced by fungi. The degradation of mycotoxins is often hindered by their resistance to traditional removal methods, but the nanomaterials investigated in this study demonstrate enhanced catalytic activity. This paper provides a critical analysis of the effectiveness and limitations of these nanomaterials in degrading mycotoxins, with a focus on their potential applications in food safety and environmental remediation. The source data is limited to the abstract, and further details regarding the specific nanomaterials, degradation processes, and experimental conditions are not provided.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: This study investigated the effects of T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by certain Fusarium species, on three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. The results showed that T-2 toxin exposure led to decreased metabolic activity, reduced levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) and heat shock protein 27 (HSP27), and lower concentrations of 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG). The toxin also altered immune function, decreasing interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-8 (IL-8) levels in a dose- and time-dependent manner. The study's findings highlight the adverse effects of T-2 toxin on cellular processes and immune response in chicken liver cells, potentially informing mitigation strategies in the poultry industry.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles

summary: This case report documents the management of severe skin damage resulting from the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion, a medication used to treat mucormycosis in an immunocompromised patient. The patient, a 36-year-old diabetic woman, developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions including the use of silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress successfully managed the injury. The skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation by day 155. This report highlights the importance of careful administration and management of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion to prevent such complications. The interaction between the medication, the patient's compromised immune system, and the resulting skin damage serves as a site of environmental rupture where human-nonhuman interactions exceed human design.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria and their combinations in relation to clinical outcomes in burn patients. We conducted a retrospective cohort study of all patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. Criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) (Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) (P < 0.001). Plasma qPCR was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) combined with species-specific plasma qPCR enhance timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. Mortality correlated with the number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment. summary: This study examined the characteristics of mycological criteria for diagnosing invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injuries. The research involved a retrospective cohort study of 276 patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023, with a focus on those having ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. The study found that among 489 positive samples, 281 were skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 were plasma specimens via species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) for Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium. Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 were found in 93 patients (33.7%), with Aspergillus being the most common (25.7%), followed by Mucorales (10.9%) and Fusarium (9.8%). The study also found that mortality rose with the number of positive criteria, with 46.7% of patients with ≥5 positive criteria experiencing death. Furthermore, plasma qPCR was found to be positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement, highlighting the importance of combining skin biopsies with species-specific plasma qPCR for timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. The study's findings underscore the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB1‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB1.
summary: This paper investigates the effects of dietary curcumin supplementation on broilers exposed to aflatoxin B1, a mycotoxin commonly found in improperly stored poultry feed. The results show that curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers. The protective effects of curcumin are attributed to the activation of the Nrf2 pathway and inhibition of the NLRP3 inflammasome. Aflatoxin B1 induces hepatic oxidative stress and inflammation in broilers, leading to growth retardation. The study suggests that dietary curcumin supplementation can mitigate the adverse effects of aflatoxin B1 exposure in broilers.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.
summary: This study examines the effects of specific mutations in the cyp51A gene of Aspergillus fumigatus on resistance to azole antifungal drugs. The researchers focused on the TR34-mediated resistance genotype, which is a particular mutation that contributes to the development of resistance. They analyzed the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on azole affinity and susceptibility, specifically the SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S, as well as combinations of these mutations. The study used CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing to introduce these mutations into a wild-type A. fumigatus strain and conducted in vitro susceptibility testing to confirm the observed azole phenotypes. The results showed that strains carrying combination mutations, particularly TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S, exhibited highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole, indicating a high level of resistance to these drugs.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antifungal compounds from soil microbes and isolated a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1 , from Kitasatospora melanogena . This compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity, with MICs of 4–16 μg/mL against Aspergillus fumigatus , Aspergillus flavus , Candida albicans , and Cryptococcus neoformans . Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus compared to the wild-type. To understand the underlying mechanism, we performed a transcriptomic analysis of A. fumigatus exposed to compound 1 , revealing a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated reactive oxygen species levels. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. IMPORTANCE Fungal infections cause substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide, yet current treatments are limited and increasingly undermined by resistance. Natural products remain a proven source of antifungal agents, but few new scaffolds have been introduced in recent decades. We identified a novel polyene macrolide from Kitasatospora melanogena with potent activity against major fungal pathogens. This compound disrupts both the fungal cell wall and membrane while inducing oxidative stress, revealing a multifaceted mechanism of action. summary: This paper reports on the identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound, compound 1, isolated from the soil microbe Kitasatospora melanogena. The compound exhibits potent antifungal activity against four major fungal pathogens, including Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, Candida albicans, and Cryptococcus neoformans, with minimum inhibitory concentrations ranging from 4 to 16 μg/mL. Treatment with compound 1 disrupts the cell wall and membrane of A. fumigatus, leading to significant growth reduction. A transcriptomic analysis reveals that compound 1 downregulates genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induces oxidative stress, resulting in elevated levels of reactive oxygen species. The multifaceted mechanisms of action of compound 1 highlight the potential of natural products from soil microbes in the development of novel antifungal agents.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study investigated how doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) influence tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three cuboidal CuS MNPs─undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS)─were foliarly applied to Fusarium-infected plants in a greenhouse study. Fe-CuS led to the highest Cu accumulation in leaves─15.7 and 158.4% higher than undoped CuS and Ce-CuS, respectively, likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient NPs uptake. Compared to the untreated control, the Fe-CuS foliar application resulted in a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS MNPs as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. Importantly, copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link Cu homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings underscore the significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, though long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts warrant further evaluation.
summary: This paper examines the impact of doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles on tomato resistance to fungal pathogens, specifically Fusarium. Three types of CuS micronanoparticles were applied to infected plants: undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS). The iron-doped CuS nanoparticles exhibited the highest copper accumulation in tomato leaves, likely due to their positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient uptake. The Fe-CuS treatment resulted in a significant increase in shoot biomass and reduction in wilt damage through the activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling. This suggests that CuS nanoparticles may act as both micronutrient carriers and immune stimulants in plants. The study also identifies a potential link between copper homeostasis and stress-induced hydrogen peroxide production through the activation of copper amine oxidases (CuAOs). This finding highlights a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity and underscores the potential for CuS nanoparticles as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, although further evaluation of long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts is necessary.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). In this study, we established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. Target genes corresponding to major fungicide classes were deleted by homologous recombination, and the resulting mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides compared with the wild-type strain. Deletion of genes encoding known fungicide targets revealed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting MoA prediction. Using the platform that detects sensitivity differences through OD₆₀₀ changes, we examined a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules and identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development. Collectively, this platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with broad applicability to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. IMPORTANCE This study provides a perspective on developing strategies to manage fungal pathogens with implications for agriculture and food security. The effectiveness of current fungicides is increasingly limited by resistance, narrow target ranges, and environmental concerns. By combining genetic approaches with chemical screening, this work offers a more systematic way to identify candidate antifungal agents and better understand their possible mechanisms. The framework may also be adapted for use in other areas, including medical and veterinary applications, suggesting potential broader applicability. summary: This paper presents a study on identifying novel antifungal compounds against the fungal pathogen Fusarium graminearum. The researchers established a systematic screening platform using gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and discover new compounds. By deleting genes encoding known fungicide targets, the mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides, allowing the researchers to predict the modes of action of the compounds. A chemical library of 2,704 small molecules was screened, and 8 compounds were identified with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway, several of which exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity. The platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with potential applications in agriculture, food security, and beyond.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Lipin, a phosphatidic acid phosphatase, catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol (TAG) biosynthesis, and acts as a transcriptional coregulator of lipid metabolism. In this study, the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under submerged (SmF) and solid-state fermentation (SSF). Under SSF, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid (TFA) content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-qPCR indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 h under SSF, coinciding with upregulation of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing TAG biosynthesis under SSF for potential industrial lipid production.
summary: This paper reports on the homologous overexpression of phosphatidate phosphatase (Lipin) in the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11. The research involved modifying the fungus's genetic makeup to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under two different conditions: static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation. The results show that overexpressing the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 significantly enhanced lipid accumulation, particularly under solid-state fermentation. The fungus's cell dry weight increased by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia, while total fatty acid content rose by 35.7% in mycelia. Fatty acid profiling revealed changes in the proportions of certain fatty acids, including increased levels of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3, and reduced levels of C18:1. Gene expression analysis indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 hours under solid-state fermentation, coinciding with the upregulation of genes involved in lipid metabolism. These findings suggest that modifying the fungus's genetic makeup can reprogram its lipid metabolism, leading to enhanced triacylglycerol biosynthesis and potential industrial applications.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. The most common underlying clinical conditions among patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%). Out of 107 patients, eight died (8/107, 7.5%); six of these deaths occurred in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and two in patients with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species. In contrast, the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii. summary: This study reports on the molecular characterization of 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. The isolates were identified as belonging to 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The findings reveal a diverse range of Aspergillus species, including A. sydowii, A. calidoustus, A. nidulans, A. tanneri, and A. terreus, which exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. The study highlights the importance of species-level identification, with PCR sequencing confirming species identity in over 88% of isolates. The results also suggest that certain Aspergillus species, such as A. tanneri and A. calidoustus, may exhibit variable susceptibility to triazoles and amphotericin B, underscoring the need for further research into the antifungal resistance of these species.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: This paper presents a study on the production of gliotoxin, a mycotoxin classified as an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, in clinical fungal isolates. The researchers analyzed 140 isolates from two major hospitals using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) and found gliotoxin production exclusively in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates. The study also identified distinct ETP-related pathways in other Aspergillus species, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus terreus, which produced aspirochlorine derivatives and aranotin-related metabolites, respectively. This research clarifies the species-specific profiles of ETP toxins in fungal isolates and confirms Aspergillus fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the examined isolates. The findings suggest that Aspergillus species interact with their environment in complex ways, producing diverse mycotoxins in response to various culture conditions.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: This paper reports the isolation and characterization of decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids from the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. The compounds exhibit cytotoxic activity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116, with IC50 values ranging from 7.3 to 79.3 μM. Additionally, certain compounds demonstrate significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria, with MIC values between 1.6 and 13.0 μg/mL. The structure-bioactivity relationship of these compounds is explored. The biosynthetic pathway for compounds 1 and 2 is proposed.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. MoldVision is a deep-learning approach that uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). Compared to experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. Our results demonstrate that CNNs integrated with low-cost smartphone imaging can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings. summary: This paper documents the development and evaluation of a deep-learning approach called MoldVision, which utilizes smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. The study analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera and generated over 4,000 images using a standardized smartphone setup. A convolutional neural network (CNN) was trained on these images and benchmarked against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments. The best-performing CNN model achieved a mean AUROC of 92.7% and sensitivity of 68.7% across all species, with particularly high performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. The study found that early-stage classification was challenging but improved significantly over time, with the CNN model outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, particularly in resource-limited settings.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus. Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. Furthermore, we demonstrated that GSNOR is important for reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial ROS levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. summary: This study investigates the role of S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) in the nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathway of Aspergillus flavus, a saprophytic filamentous fungus responsible for aflatoxin production. The research demonstrates that GSNOR is essential for maintaining NO homeostasis, and its deletion results in elevated NO levels, impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, and decreased aflatoxin production. Furthermore, GSNOR deletion impacts the balance of reactive oxygen species (ROS), leading to increased mycelial ROS levels and heightened sensitivity to oxidative stress. The findings suggest that GSNOR plays a crucial role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis, highlighting the potential of targeting components in the NO signaling pathway as a novel strategy for aflatoxin contamination prevention. The study's results underscore the complex interactions between fungal organisms, industrial materials (in this case, food products), and environmental factors, underscoring the need for a deeper understanding of multispecies assemblages in the Anthropocene.
